Destroying the nexus itself, either by dispelling the magic or simply damaging it until it can't hold itself together, is the easiest way to get rid of a banffia swarm without dealing with tens or hundreds of magical explosions.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The astronesth can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Light Absorption
entries: Whenever the astronesth is subjected to radiant damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the radiant damage dealt.

trait.name: Void Aura
entries: The astronesth emits a 15-foot radius sphere of magical darkness centered on itself. No mundane or magical light can exist within this area, and a creature with darkvision cannot see through it. A source of light is suppressed while within the area of darkness, but may resume shedding light when it leaves the area.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Aphosic Drain {@recharge 5}
entries: The astronesthattempts to consume all sources of light within 30 feet of itself. A light source is automatically extinguished if:
- it is not being worn or carried by a creature
- it is not a magic item
- it is not larger than 15 feet on a side

If a light source is being worn or carried by a creature, the creature must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, avoiding the effect on a success, or being subject to the effect as normal on a failure.
If a light source is a magical item activated by expending charges, it may be reactivated by using the appropriate number of charges; otherwise, the item loses its ability to shed light for 1 day.
If a light source is larger than 15 feet on a side, a spherical portion of the light source 15 feet in diameter ceases to shed light, following all previous rules.

{@b If this effect extinguishes a spell, the radius of Void Aura increases by 5 feet for each level of spell extinguished. If it extinguishes a cantrip, there is a {@chance 10} chance that the radius increases by 5 feet. Spells are affected as follows:}
- The {@spell Light} cantrip is extinguished, regardless of the size of the object.
- All lights created by {@spell Dancing Lights} in range are extinguished, but other lights created by the spell are not affected.
- The effects of {@spell Faerie Fire} end for any creature in range creature

- The area created by {@spell Daylight} is treated as a light source larger than 15 feet on a side, and each activation of this ability darkens a 15-foot diameter sphere within the area, unless the spell was cast targeting a specific object, in which case the object is treated as the source of light. If the object is smaller than 15 feet on a side, it is extinguished and the spell ends; if the object is larger than 15 feet on a side, it is treated as a light source of the appropriate size, and the spell ends once its entire surface has been affected.
- The length of a {@spell Wall of Light} is reduced by 10 feet.
- Other spells that create a light source may be partially or fully extinguished by this ability, but any other effects of the spell are unaffected.

bonus.name: Nova
entries: When the astronesth successfully uses Aphosic Drain, it may use its bonus action to trigger one of the following effects:
- the astronesth regains 9 ({@dice 2d8}) hit points, and each stareater in within its Void Aura regains 2 ({@dice 1d4}) hit points.

- all creatures that can see the astronesth within 40 feet of it (ignoring the effects of Void Aura) must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, as the astronesth releases a searing flash of light. A creature that fails the saving throw is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. Stareaters and other astronesths are immune to this effect.

- the astronesth flashes an entrancing pattern of lights. Three creatures of its choice within 30 feet of it must make {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throws, becoming {@condition charmed} until the end of their next turn on a failure.

Stareaters are large (~3 ft.), sleek, streamlined fish, with pitch-black scales and a row of light organs running down either side of their bodies. While this appearance alone is remarkable, it is their hunting behavior that makes them truly unique. Their long, thin, semi-translucent teeth indicate that they might eat smaller fish, but this is far from the truth. In fact, stareaters, as their name, suggests, consume light itself.

Few trustworthy descriptions of stareaters exist. Most eyewitness accounts describe a black streak in the water, a splash, and then darkness. As if they weren't already difficult enough to spot, stareaters only venture into shallow water on nights when the moon is not visible. At all other times, they live in the depths, beyond where sunlight penetrates, subsisting on the glow of bioluminescent bacteria and other flashing critters. But on moonless nights, they surface, seeking the lamps of boats and fishermen. The lucky ones might even find an adventuring party, with all sorts of magical lights to feast upon.

Stareaters are not inherently aggressive; while they will pursue bright sources of light with reckless abandon, they are unlikely to intentionally attack or harm creatures larger than themselves. Schools of trained stareaters are sometimes used by the aquatic races as a first line of defense to hide valuable secrets from prying eyes without resorting to violence.
{@b Astronesths}

A stareater that has gorged itself on magic light can mutate into an astronesth. Astronesths are much larger than an average stareater, and emit an intense aura of magical darkness that seems to suck light into itself. While no more evil than a regular stareater, an astronesth is only ever truly sated by magic light, and is therefore much more agressive and willing to attack creatures to get a meal.
